Detailed Description

Extends Aria's ArAction so as to provide a means for hooking into the Pioneer robot event call chain.

Usage

The RmActionHandler provided during construction need only implement the RmActionHandler::handleAction() method, which will be called each time a robot event is fired. The following executable example demonstrates how a handler might be installed. 

 1    #include "PioneerController\RmPioneerController.h"
 2    #include "PioneerController\RmActionHandler.h"
 3
 4    class MyActionHandler : public RmActionHandler
 5    {
 6         void handleAction( ArRobot* robot )
 7         {
 8              // Do synchronous stuff here
 9         }
 10   };
 11
 12   void main( int argc, char* argv[] )
 13   {
 14        MyActionHandler handler;
 15        RmPioneerController robot( true, true, &handler );
 16        while ( robot.isRunning() ) {
 17             // Do asynchronous stuff here
 18        }
 19   }
Line 15 sets the robot up for an asynchronous wander mode (see RmPioneerController::RmPioneerController() for details). Once the robot is running, each time the robot dispatches an action event, the handleAction() method beginning on line 6 is executed.

Dependencies

None.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

RmActionHook::RmActionHook (  RmActionHandler *  actionHandler  ) 
 

Sets up the given RmActionHandler as the handler for this particular hook into the robot event chain.

It will be called each time an Aria action event is fired.

Member Function Documentation

ArActionDesired * RmActionHook::fire (  ArActionDesired  currentDesired  )  [virtual]
 

The ArAction method that is called by the robot event chain to execute this particular action.

Dispatches the event to the RmActionHandler registered with this hook.
